pros: Health benefit plan, vacation and holiday paid time off.
cons: As an employee hired into a position with a “level 1” behind they’re job title you’re expected to learn and start using many unique computer portals within a month of starting. You’re expected to read and know the specifics of 5+ research protocols while still within training period. The backlog of unfinished work given to one person to complete is impossible to finish while being expected to stay current on present responsibilities. Current responsibilities include meeting face to face with patients, so you have to keep this part of learning at the top of your priorities list. If you like to learn at a pace where you’ll remember what you learned from week to week, or to feel like you’ve done a good job by keeping up with your assigned work, you won’t be happy in this position.

review_title: Not a friendly place to work.
pros: The pros of working at MUSC are very few. The pay was decent.
cons: I worked at MUSC for 2.5 years and never felt valued or welcomed. I enjoy a challenge at work and am always looking for ways to make things better for everyone. At MUSC your ideas are ignored or blocked. In the 2.5 years that I worked there, I was never told "YES". The important things that needed to be implemented to help faculty and students be more successful were always blocked. I have worked at many universities and have never encountered so many issues or such a poorly organized institution. If you are one of the "chosen" ones you walk on water and can do no wrong. But if you are just a number you feel devalued and disengaged. For example, I reported, on several occasions some unethical practices at the university but I was ignored. It becomes very difficult to drag yourself to work every day knowing that you and your team are always ignored. Be careful where you chose to work.

review_title: Decent work, but low pay and average benefits.
pros: They were pretty reasonable with the software development lifecycle, incorporating sprints and planning in a meaningful way, and management listened to concerns regarding various development issues that crept up now and again
cons: Management and HR flat out refused promotions. When I had left, I had just helped secure a $12Mil contract for research and software development related to that research. After helping secure it, the department head took 40% off the top and announced her retirement. HR/Management told me they couldn't "afford" to pay me more after I had helped secure the contract, so I left for a better position and pay elsewhere at the end of the next two weeks. MUSC also seemed to hire developers simply to meet their diversity quota, which was just demeaning to the new hires, who were either over or under-qualified. For all of their talk about diversity (which, I guess is good?) it just felt like a façade, disingenuous. While neither of these practices were exceedingly bad, it was enough to make me want to leave.

pros:
Benefits are good, overall. Tuition reimbursement is definitely helpful if you're a working student.

In terms of work environment, I've worked in two entities (MUHA and University) and my teams have been great, generally speaking. Complacency is often ignored by managers, which definitely affects overall team morale.
cons:
Parking is a nightmare. The only free parking available is a bus ride or 15-20 minute walk from campus, depending on where you work. Wait lists for parking garages take forever (I've worked here since 2018 and am still 514th in line for a spot that costs $70/month).

Salaries are totally inadequate compared to the increasingly high cost of living in Charleston. HR determines compensation, so getting a raise is a futile effort, even with the recommendation/advocation of a supervisor. HR seems to take advantage of the over-saturation of health professionals in this area to offer lower wages.

The fact that you have to use a certain amount of PTO before you're allowed to use sick leave is absurd. Mandating PTO on days administrative offices are closed (i.e. the week between Christmas and New Years, closures for hurricanes) is equally frustrating.

Hospital admins seem completely out of touch with the experiences and needs of healthcare workers.

job_title: Program Coordinator I in Charleston, SC
pros:
Only applies to the University; MUHA (the hospital) is completely different. 

1. Good PTO package
2. Good health insurance
3. Opportunities to network
4. Easy to transfer across internal positions 
5. Growing diversity among staff, faculty, and students
6. Finding a team with leaders who support and advocate for their staff will make your experience here so much more enjoyable!
cons:
1. Leadership (I.e. presidents council, board of trustees) have good intentions, but are so far removed from the everyday interworkings of this enterprise. They make decisions with very little to zero awareness of what actually goes on in the lower levels of the hierarchy (AKA the backbone of this enterprise)
2. HORRIBLE pay, unless you’re tenured faculty
3. The parking situation downtown is disastrous. Don’t be fooled by “free parking” in Hagood; This just means there are a couple hundred first come first serve spots to serve the thousands of students, staff, and volunteers who work downtown.

job_title: Recruitment Marketing Strategist/Provider Sourcing Strategist in Charleston, SC
pros:
- Good Medical benefits (but very expensive and only one option)
- Generous (but confusing) PTO policy
cons:
- The position I interviewed for and the work I did were incredibly different. I was told I would be creating social media posts and running campaigns, developing content, have the ability to introduce some new technology into the aging medical community... I did none of that but create a little content and only because I had to send some emails. You will be a glorified admin writing job descriptions and doing the recruiter's work.
- Incredibly old technology... ATS is difficult to navigate and pretty useless for building pipelines. Only sourcing technologies are for active candidates, not passive ones. Not willing to spend money to upgrade to new technology... would rather pay vendors for one-off work (which is even more expensive). That, or they will pay thousands of dollars to post in a professional journal that will yield maybe 2 people in total, neither of which will be qualified. 
- Everything is active recruiting, waiting on people to apply... you have no tools to do any passive sourcing, can't even get Recruiter Lite because as one recruiter put it, "not a lot of health professionals are on LinkedIn." 
- Recruiters have 5 people in a pipeline and act like the world is going to fall upon them they are so busy. You will have to handhold them through every step (some are older and don't get any sort of technology) and when you try to teach them they will just tell you, "that's your job to do it for me." I built a simple spreadsheet to help track priority and one recruiter told me that she, "does not do or understand spreadsheets and won't be using it." 
- Everything is just... slow. Want a job approved, maybe in 2 weeks. Want a description approved, 2 weeks. Need someone to finalize the approval process, another week. Then they wonder why they can't attract top-tier candidates.
- Director is more than happy to tell you all about the "amazing" people he has placed and all the companies he has built because he is so incredible. This is also after he made the comment that he, "was happy to have another man in the office because he had to work with all women already." 
- You will not be doing any real marketing... all of that has to run through.. you guessed it, the actual marketing department, which won't give you access to anything.
- Finally, while they do have good benefits, there is only one plan for MUSCP and they are incredibly expensive

review_title: Great place to work, some issue to be dealt with
pros:
MUHA & MUSC provide a great experience.  The hospital offers many things to the customer which are not available at other institutions.  These services draw patients in from all corners of the state.  These services also save lives and provide people with good outcomes.
The benefits package is very nice.  Because it is a State Authority, the employees can be part of the State Pension, State Insurance and many other great opportunities.  Education benefits are also great, and have not been cut or curtailed by budget cuts.  
The other 'pros' are too long to list: Healthclub memberships(reduced rate), Health Screenings(reduced cost), holiday meal plans...
cons:
Many people assume that in the south, it is who you know not what you know.  That is a major problem here.  Some managers/directors have been in the same position for 25+ years.  They have not changed with the times, and now good staff are leaving because the old management style does not work.  
Sometimes, hours and expectations lead to poor work/life balance, and MUSC does not seem to care about this like they used to.  The business model here has changed to "employees are replaceable" and not a retention of employees mindset.

review_title: Terrible place to work, incompetent and selfish leadership, stressful in both hospital and university.Treats staff badly
pros: Charleston, SC.  This has to be the only reason one would continue to work here- to be close to the gorgeous downtown and beaches.  There are only a handful of companies and organizations in Charleston- the two biggest:  MUSC and Boeing  (and Boeing is mostly subcontractors).  Those who work here feel the need to talk it up, not because hospital work is noble (and it is) but rather because they all know they are easily replaced.  I don't know anyone who actually likes MUSC - from drs, teachers, nurses, staff, postdocs- they may like their chosen field, but not MUSC - it is not a happy place.  USC has better schools and accepts stronger students and the Upstate has much better facilities, doctors and patient reviews. Look it up. Unless they stop hiring more-of-the-same leadership, the institution will continue to sink.
cons:
Leasership without any university experience and Board of trustees that purposely closes out the community and kicking out all strong female leadership = poorly run institution.  
The amount employees spend on health benefits is insane, especially since you work at a hospital!!  In fact, you will likely pay more than someone working outside of heathcare and you are basically forced to see MUSC drs or pay even more!
When the city floods- you are still expected to drive to work. Lord help you if you have a low riding car, because at some point, you will stall and possibly float on some of the roads around MUSC.  Right after you pay high rates for your parking.  Alternatively, you can walk across a dangerous highway, in the rain.

pros: My co-workers are wonderful. The reputation of the University - especially the research areas - is one of the reasons why I wanted to work here. It is well-respected in the community.
cons: The University and the Hospital fall under the same "MUSC" name. However, the University is a state agency and the Hospital is not. This causes a lot of problems because the University must abide by the strict regulations mandated by the Budget & Control Board. The Hospital pays much better and the University cannot be as competitive because of the outdated and unreasonable pay band structure. Also, the bureaucracy and politics of a state agency means there are so many hoops to jump through just to get one thing approved that a lot of time is wasted. The University is serious about hierarchy, which drives me crazy!

review_title: Company has a great mission, but is bogged down by state rules and bad long-term employees
pros: This hospital is truly changing what's possible in health care. There are so many doctors, nurses and researchers who are here because they chose to be here--many of whom cut their teeth at Mayo, Cleveland Clinic, Johns Hopkins, etc. It's easy to buy in to the mission of MUSC.
cons: As a state authority, MUHA (the hospital entity) gets to choose which state benefits it enacts and denies, depending on how it affects the bottom line. PTO, salaries, bonuses (ha), raises (ha again) and benefits are pathetic. We don't even get reimbursed for mileage when we drive to off-site work events. Also, too many leaders have been in their positions too long--and it's impossible to fire them, despite their poor performances.

review_title: Great for experience, not so great as a longterm gig
pros:
Great for experience in mental health care or trying to get into a health care degree program
Very rewarding work
Some coworkers and patients start to feel like family
Great benefits
Decent pay if you have at least a Bachelors
cons:
Management is often unhelpful and disorganized.
Always short staffed, large number of people quitting due to lack of teamwork, treatment from management, and burnout from working around the mentally ill with little support
Something you really have to have a passion for to do full-time or long term because it can be very demanding work physically and mentally (this can be a pro or a con depending)
Lack of teamwork, hard getting certain nurses to take initiative and pitch in with daily patient care
Not enough compensation for all the work you do and abuse you take from patients

job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Charleston, SC
pros:
Decent benefits
-Im fortunate to have a great boss and team members. We work well together as a team and individually.
cons:
-Pay is menial for the role. COL is no longer an excuse to not pay employees as Charleston COL is currently and here on in, through the roof. 
-As with most academic institutions, suits and white hairs despise and therefore prevent change--with the trickle down effect, everyone below them also resists and fears change as well. This prevents growth as an employee and as a department, and also maintains inconsistency.
- Even when your roles change and your load is tripled--essentially your entire job changes, you will still not be considered for a raise. I was told that even though my job changed dramatically, it is still under the same umbrella as "Program Coordinator". Unfair. 
-Dont expect a raise anytime soon. Advocating for yourself and the contributions you know you bring to the department will not lead to a raise.

pros: Benefits are pretty good and you feel secure that you won't get laid off.  Even though it's not perfect nor by far the best place to work in SC, most employees seem glad to work here and take pride in their work.
cons: You get a small raise every year, if that.  Parking is a pain, you have to park several blocks away and take a shuttle to work.  Doctors are given special treatment.  Upper management makes an effort to communicate information to the rank and file but there is a huge lack of communication between employees in different departments.  Even though we are implementing electronic medical records, very little IT training is offered to employees which a lot of employees REALLY need.  Sure they offer training in the medical record software, but many employees need basic training on basic IT skills, like how to use a mouse, or how to save a document in the right folder.

pros: Because MUSC is so large, there are plenty of opportunities to choose from for jobs. MUSC has many resources to draw from considering it is a teaching hospital. I have met many good friends working there over the years.
cons: Where do I begin? It has a culture of bullying, discrimination both ways, short cuts, and concealment. Management does not tell you what is happening in the hospital. The bottom line is about money not about patients getting better or for the safety of staff. There is zero work-life balance. If you have a problem, don't go to Human Resources. HR will turn around and call your manager and the process of getting rid of you will begin. There is currently a mass exodus of staff who have finally said enough is enough! Consider yourself warned.

review_title: Avoid this place if you can.
pros: Schedule was flexible which was nice for school and sudden events.
cons: Management is clueless when it comes to running a business. They are stuck in the healthcare model from 40 years ago. Turnover is very high, employee satisfaction was almost nonexistent. Except on the University side, those people loved their jobs, but the hospital side is a totally different story. You are treated like garbage by your coworkers and managers. Good employees are used and abused until they quit. Bad employees are praised because they are the only on left. You will be subjected to numerous consulting companies sometimes 2 a year who tell the same info yet it is never followed. It is a messy place to work. In the end, I worked there but I would NEVER be a patient there.

job_title: Administrative Specialist II  in Charleston, SC

cons: Poor upward mobility and community recruitment for management positions. Also, the bonus programs are not distributed equally among members of the staff. For example weekend only bonus pay only applys to RN's and not support staff that also work weekends. The merit raises that are given are insulting.

review_title: Your Experience as a GA will likely depend highly on the particular Department in which you're hired
pros: There are some decent fringe benefits as an MUSC employee. Beyond that, there honestly aren't too many pros of working there, honestly. At least not in the Department I was in, though I've heard that varies widely from dept to dept.
cons: Technology & software (for Administrators) are very outdated; severely understaffed, and then of course overworked to compensate for under-staffing; minimal training and guidance in getting you acquainted with the job; faculty will have high expectations and all assume you are their personal administrator rather than understanding that you are working for the entire faculty of the Dept.; very poor upper management; very poor communication within the Dept and the larger university; very antiquated way of doing everything; out of touch with today's standards of professionalism, workplace expectations, empowering employees, etc.

job_title: Administrative Coordinator I in Charleston, SC
pros: MUSC is pretty competitive in the salaries in the area.  You meet a large number of people and they are very nice.  The benefits are excellent!
cons: There is not enough parking spaces for employee to park.  We have to take the shuttle to get work.  They do not give a grace period; you are considered late if you are 1 minute late, which is very unfair considering you have to take a shuttle to work.  MUSC does not consider gving the employees that work here advancement opportunites.  They would generally hire someone from the outside before they consider people on the inside unless it is upper management. Also, things are always changing (i.e. software, computer programs,) you always have to learn new systems and then when you learn it, they change it again.

pros: Health benefits are great. Management is willing to work with you almost anytime you need off. It is a highly regarded facility. Most co-workers are respectful of one another. Very rewarding when patients respect you.
cons: Management has to many bosses above them; they are constantly trying to please their supervisors who all want different things. 75% of the time you will not be appreciated for what you do (by patients and family members) unless you are a doctor. You can be spit on, kicked, punched, have fecal matter thrown at you, be verbally abused, and sexually harrassed by patients; usually by altered mental status patients but sometimes by the normals. Frequently sick due to constantly being around sick people.

review_title: MUSC Department of Public Safety with Officers that not only believe in Protect and Serve but cares.
job_title: State Security Officer in Charleston, SC
pros: MUSC itself is so diverse.  They have MUHA, UMA, and University that make up MUSC.  There are so many Departments in each group.  All are working towards the same goals. To improve upon Customer Service from every angle.
cons: The biggest downside is the availability of parking.  Parking Spaces available for the patients are plentiful.  Available spaces for Employees are packed.  Paid parking spaces have long waiting lists.  The Free Parking lots are full by 7:45 am majority of the time.  Spaces are scarce until 2:00pm.  The spaces then start to open up.

review_title: MUSC only cares about perception not actual change
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Charleston, SC
pros: Good benefits and great PTO that's the only good thing about MUSC. And there is no limit on how much you can cash out
cons: Where to begin... Ultimately you feel like a little cog in the machine that will get groused up and will spit you out. Manager only care about covering their but so ull constantly will be made sign "counseling" reports. Training is paid but completely useless and is there for only legal and compliance purposes. Raise policy is ridiculous and at best you might get 25 cents per year if you jump through all ridiculous hoops. At the end of the day they care more about image and perception rather real change and quality

review_title: Great job if you have low expectations
pros: Job security. Look around and you’ll quickly learn that you won’t be fired based on poor job performance.
cons: The administration is not accommodating or appreciative of its employees. Must pay $30-$100/month for parking that is off campus and requires you to be shuttled in by bus on a very unreliable and seemingly nonexistent bus schedule. Every small task is an act of Congress. Difficult to get reimbursed for company expenses. Difficult to book meeting locations. Difficult to pay invoices. Incompetent IT department makes job even more difficult. Some people work 80 hours per week with no bonus, no promotion, and a maximum of a 4% raise. Also, employee work spaces are cramped, outdated and very minimalistic. Bathrooms are old and gross, too.

pros: Research position in academia.  very laid back atmosphere.  No set work hours depending on who you are working for...just get your work done!.Wear jeans to work!  Low pressure position, yet exciting.  Very collaborative environment with weekly seminars, journal clubs.
cons: typical grant sponsored positions.  make hay while the sun is shining and be ready to move on when the money runs out.  No real security if you are being paid from a federal grant as a research technician.  Hours can be long at times and if you're working in cell biology research, expect to be working regularly on the weekends.  Cells don't have a 40 hour work week

pros: State employee benefits. Fantastic salary for the workload. Typical full-time workweek is 35 hours or less. University environment. Great locale near the ocean.
cons: Good old boy gamesmanship & politics at the Director level and above. Cost restraints restrict safety & efficiency improvements. Several director-level  positions staffed by contractors that are retired managers, thus restricting upward mobility for staff and defeating the state-mandated retirement for employees reaching 28 years of service. HR is most concerned with avoiding lawsuits; HR management informed me that they always settle employee  lawsuits filed by five local law firms but didn't mention which five firms.

review_title: The university is great, specific labs in research vary. If one in a nice lab, it is a great overall
pros: Employee benefits, Hospital cafeteria, Writing centre, assistance with employee issues, down town location, oppurtunities for growth, wellness activities
cons: Mostly a hospital...so there are fewer labs to shift into with respect to research. Therefore choice of lab for research is important. Postdoc salary is low and can be fired without notice even if one is international and depends on the job for VISA and stay. Can lead to few unpleasant issues.

review_title: Overall a Nice Place to Work
pros: Staff is very nice to work with, especially in the pediatric areas. As with any nursing population there is always some degree of petty infighting, but not nearly as much as are in some other places. I would have stayed there indefinitely if I could have adjusted my hours to accommodate my family and young kids.
cons: Understaffing issues are pervasive, and are a stressor to nursing staff. There are many medical students, who are generally very nice, but you must be vigilant of their orders as they are learning so that patients are not harmed. It can be depressing because it is a hospital where the most critical patients are treated.

pros: Great location, friendly people, and received excellent training.  Plenty of time given for learning, and didn't spend too much time scutted.
cons: Salary on the low side for cost of living but my program had a generous book fund.  Getting the budget to replace support staff who left was problematic.

pros: My schedule is fairly flexible and I get medical benefits
cons: Poor management. Poor pay and rarely ever see raises from what I hear from employees who have worked here for much longer. Benefits are okay, but I get more taken out of my paycheck for my benefits than I did at my previous job and I can ONLY be seen at MUSC if I don't want to pay a lot... which is hard because appointments are several weeks out.

review_title: A steady paycheck but that's about it.
job_title: Patient Registration Representative in Charleston, SC
pros: The only thing that kept me going to that job everyday was a steady paycheck. I worked with some nice people as well but that's about it.
cons: I was constantly dealing with one rude patient after another and trying to solve problems that had been created somewhere else in the healthcare system. The pay is nowhere near what it needs to be for people to put up with this day after day.

pros: Wonderful colleagues. Many physicians and faculty are great to work with.
cons: Nepotism!  Good old boy network of retired elderly white males still run many of the administrative functions. Mandatory state retirement after 33 years of state service but University hires the retiring managers & Directors to stay on as contractors in their same positions. Thus upward mobility is limited. Cost cutting continues to take priority over growth or safety. Physician leadership has improved the hospital but the University side is under a separate Sr. VP biding her time until retirement. Many of the top researchers have left or are leaving for other Univetsities. We speculate MUSC is giving up on research and focusing on health care and teaching.

review_title: Good Job Security but Misleading on Several Things
job_title: Help Desk Technician in Charleston, SC
pros: There is good job security here.  Fortunately, it is such a big company if you aren’t happy in one department you can move to another one fairly easy.  They also contribute to your retirement plan so that's a plus.  Management does not breathe down your neck so you can work without feeling micro managed.
cons:
Well, as others have said it's an old boys club, so I won't dwell on that.  Parking is a hassle but better than it used to be.  There still are waiting lists for decent parking which take a few months and then you have to pay for parking, $30-50 a month depending on which lot. 

You also have to use your PTO to take off for holidays, which is fine for clinical staff that doesn't work a regular 8 to 5 schedule, but for those of us who work office hours, you have to use your PTO, so even though they say you get 23 days of vacation a year, you have to use your PTO for holidays, so in reality you only get 11 days of vacation per year and you have to use that for sick time as well.  

Also, they don't tell you this until you're hired but you HAVE to contribute at least 6% of your salary to the retirement plan so keep that in mind during salary negotiations.

Another thing they are rather deceitful about is their dental plans.  At orientation the benefits administrator practically coerces you into signing up for the Basic Dental plan.  The way he words it, he makes it seem like Dental Plus is NOT a good plan for the money and that the Basic Dental plan is the most cost effective plan.  However, when I went to my dentist, she told me I would have to pay $80 out of pocket just for a cleaning!!! On top of that, you can’t change dental plans for two years, so you’re locked into a crappy dental plan for two years.

Yes, the Basic Plan is free to employees, however since it doesn’t even cover cleanings, it’s a waste.   It took a lot of back and forth from me with the HR dept to get them to explain the dental plans in plain English.  Finally I learned that the Basic Plan only covers 50% of expenses and the Dental Plus covers 80%.  So be sure to take the Dental Plus plan, even though it costs more, it’s worth it.

job_title: Research Specialist II in Charleston, SC
pros: The work is interesting if you're interested in the work.  A lot of PTO (10 hours sick + 10 hours vacation per month, 13 holidays, hazardous/inclement weather pay)
cons: You will never get a raise other than state-mandated cost of living increases without switching labs.  Health insurance has a large deductible that I hope that I don't ever meet; most area doctors, dentists and eye care professionals charge you less if you say you don't have insurance than if you give them this insurance info.

pros: Some great leaders in the organization who truly understand how to manage people and create meaningful relationships; senior management does a good job of being visable a creating action where it is needed. Good benefits as a state employee; very good work-life balance. Office culture can be great depending on the leader of your work unit.
cons: Very limited opportunities for continued growth, even when you proactively seek these out; upward mobility is a challenge despite numerous documented accomplishments for the department. Some individuals have been there a very long time and struggle with change or have become unpleasant in their management approach, running counter to the organization's values.

pros: Cafeteria, Dental Plus Plan, Patients
cons: Departments behave unethically and are still a good old boy network. Examples include HIPAA violations, hiring anf firing practices, hostile work environments and pettiness. The management engages in covering up any issues. Higher ups do not care about what is occuring on the ground and allows any and all infractions to occur.  Poor behavior on clinical trials to include lack of MD recognition of adverse events and reporting to poor management of femalr staff by male business managers. Their lawyers and staff will bully you.  Departments in question include all but psychology. Horrific place.

pros: Since this is such a large teaching hospital, there are opportunities for moving around the organization. They try to stay on the cutting edge of technology but are limited due to resources and people who have no vision.
cons: I have worked at the company for less than a year but the biggest problem is there is nowhere to park at the hospital. The other major con is if you have a bad manager, you are stuck with that and there is no recourse.

pros: MUSC is a good place to work overall.  People are pleasant. Benefits are decent. For the most part, mamagers are helpful and willing to work with you if you have problem, etc. Parking is expensive if you can even get a spot in a paid lot or garage.  The free parking is a daily hunt.
cons: Parking is a nightmare.  You have to get there by 715 if you want a spot for a 730/8am shift.

review_title: Amazing place to work to rack up experience
job_title: Research Specialist III in Charleston, SC
pros: Working in academia is generally a positive experience. Being surrounded by experts in the field allows you to absorb so much information towards individual betterment. You get to work in an easy-going, laid back environment where your opinions are valued and supervisors are receptive to suggestions.
cons: The pay leaves a lot to be desired, you can easily make at least twice working in the industry but you will learn at a snail's pace there. Speaking of which, HR moves S L  O   W, so don't expect administrative changes to take place anytime soon.

review_title: Everything you Need to Know about Working at MUSC
pros:
MUSC tries to hire the best academic people for the job in the sciences. I cannot speak to the hiring practices of upper administration and other fields, so I am sticking with that I know best.  We spend big bucks and lots of time to find the right candidate for the job. This is a concerted effort made by faculty and staff and it is taken very seriously. Sometimes, people get close to taking us up on a job offer and then vanish at the last minute because they got a better offer; they were holding out for a promotion where they were; or the trailing spouse nixed the deal. We are experienced in this type of disappointment and we endeavor to learn from it and improve the next candidate search.  Also, MUSC hires people with diverse backgrounds if possible. For example, we hired a theater major to do project development. He was fantastic, putting his skills to work in a novel way. So, I would say that MUSC does not use a cookie-cutter approach to hiring.
The location of MUSC is a draw. Situated on the Charleston peninsula, MUSC is the largest edifice in the city. It is visible from the bridges that take you into downtown, which makes a lovely scene as you drive to work. Arial shots of the MUSC complex always impress as the harbor water and the marina set a nautical tone while the brick buildings convey a business theme. 
Much of the downtown area around MUSC is original, meaning that the sidewalks George Washington walked over are still in there, buckled and broken, but charming in their historic appeal. MUSC works to maintain the historic aspect of its campus by replacing any brick or stone work that must be temporarily moved for new buildings and growth. We also are masterful at restoring old buildings and using them again. Breathtaking is the new College of Health Professions which is a renovated Charleston High School. It is worth viewing just for the majesty of this space.  In fact, at Christmas, I use this building's lobby for my family holiday photos...it is that gorgeous. 
As faculty, at MUSC, you are basically left alone. This is ideal. You cannot do your best work under micromanaging scrutiny and stifling meddling. Happily, at MUSC, you are independent and left to your own creativity to get the job done.  
MUSC is innovative in that it posts a rumor mill on the intranet for faculty and staff. This allows us to read what others are thinking and learn about what is going on that we might not investigate on our own. This is good and promotes transparency in administration. Often the answers are pat and reiterative of policy, which does not address the question submitted, but now and then a really good and informative answer surprises me and I learn from this web offering. 
Our cafeteria is getting an overhaul, and it was already pretty good. The salad bar is great and they are always experimenting with new ideas. We also have a farmers market that comes to us on Fridays. CAN YOU BELIEVE THIS? This is part of our healthy programs for employees, and it is a smash. I cheaply replenish my vegetable drawer in the fridge every Friday because of this opportunity, which benefits local businesses and farms. 
Because we are on the water, the graduate school often charters a huge boat to pilot around the harbor for a few hours at the beginning of the school year. This is a unique aspect of MUSC. 
We are near the College of Charleston, so we can collaborate with their faculty on ideas. Generally, we are encouraged to do this, and it makes for interesting work.
cons:
As much as I am pleased with the independence and historic charm of MUSC and this area, there are a few drawbacks I wish I had known about earlier. First, there is little parking available, and many people have been on decades' long wait lists for parking spaces in adjacent garages. New garages should alleviate this issue in the future, while new buildings often cause parking areas to be closed for many months at a time. 
I wish that MUSC had insurance and health care coverage more like other medical universities in which faculty and their family receive free care by their employer's health care providers. I received this at my previous medical university job and it was a siginificant benefit for us. I felt very valued as an employee in this regard. 
MUSC does not offer this to faculty. Also, unfortunately, health care plans that MUSC once had are no longer available and the worst choice is the state health plan which covers very little although the premiums are mandated and taken from the paycheck. Through a disturbing calculus, the state plan covers not much, but what you pay for the care does not go to the deductible or the out-of-pocket...which is suprising and depressing to people who have not been told this by HR. Thus, I would say that there is not sufficient accuracy and transparency with the health plans offered. 
Other drawbacks might be that HR is very hard to reach...you can call the entire HR directory and no one will answer the phone. This occurs many times a week , and people DO complain. HR is trying to fix this. 
Recently, we had the unfortunate experience of furloughing faculty who were not the highest earners in the university. This was troubling because faculty making substantial salaries were not furloughed, confusing many and lowering morale for those who were lower wage earners and could therefore not comfortably afford 4 months worth of mandatory paycheck deductions. Many people thought that the budget crises would have been faster solved by furloughing the highest earners instead of selectively penalizing only a handful (1,500) of people who were struggling with money matters. The budget seems to be back on track at this time, so maybe this will be a bad memory for us very soon...and not repeated.
I often feel discouraged about the reporting system at MUSC when a problem needs to be solved. Like every other workplace on the planet, we have people who like the paycheck but not the work to earn it, and they don't do their due diligence at work. Because of the convoluted reporting system and hiring structure, it is impossible to remove low performers. We recently embarked on several new policies (MUSC Excellence and new contracts for faculty) that should speed up this aspect of MUSC (incompetence in the workplace) but we have not seen results at this time. 
I don't want to go on and on about drawbacks because ultimately, you can forge your own path at MUSC. If you have an idea, you can run with it and you can develop your goals with lots of freedom. This type of academic freedom will help you divert your attention from the cons and focus on the plusses of MUSC and it can also help you change your environment. Go-getters and doggedly determined faculty tend to rise above the fray and set their own pathways.

I saw  so much nepotism that it was ridiculous.  if you are sure you would like to go into Academia or med school, please for the love of god stay as far away from the Addictive Sciences Division as you possibly can.
